results.title: Photosynthesis
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and TV Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: biology”.
Exciting 3-D computer animations show the dynamic process of photosynthesis at the molecular level. Starting with the historic discoveries of Joseph Priestley, Jan Ingenhousz and Jean Senebier, these six 10 minute episodes examine the absorption of light by plants, and follows the energy pathways to the production of carbohydrates and other organic materials. Programs also develop the Calvin cycle, as it functions in Carbon 3 and Carbon 4 plants, and the remarkable fluid transport system that delivers water and nutrients throughout the plant structure. The programs include: 1. “Seeing the light” 2. “Absorbing the light” 3. “The Light reaction” 4. “The Dark reaction” 5. “C3 and C4 plants” 6. “The Fluid transport system.”
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and TV Ontario

results.title: Organic evolution
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: biology”.
Organic evolution traces the development of various theories of evolution. It begins with the Biblical account of creation and discusses the work of Mendel, Darwin and the Hardy-Weinberg law. Examines microscopic and macroscopic organisms, genetics, heredity, cell reproduction, breeding populations, hypothesis and observation. The six episodes are entitled: 1. “In the Beginning” 2. “Darwin, naturally” 3. “Factoring in Mendel” 4. “The Meiotic mix” 5. “The Population picture” 6. “Mutation and all that.”

results.title: Homeostasis
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: biology”.
Homeostasis explores the internal systems of balance and regulation in animals. With the assistance of computer animation, sequences illustrate how the body deals with stress and copes with changing conditions such as high and low temperatures, and how the shortage or excess of fluids is adjusted and regulated. Six 10 minute episodes present students at secondary and post secondary levels with a comprehensible definition of homeostasis with examples of how it works, and how this on-going balancing of internal conditions to external changes and stimuli is triggered and monitored. Includes: 1. “Coping with change”, 2. “The Sea within”, 3. “Osmoregulation”, 4. ” The Feedback cycle”, 5. “Biochemical balances”, 6. “Hormonal control.”

results.title: Energy flow
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: biology”.
Energy flow encompasses one of the principal themes of biology: the flow of energy throughout the world of living things. Central to this concept is the process of photosynthesis, without which life could not exist. The programs deal with energy flow in organisms, within cells and the role of energy in our agricultural system. It concludes with an examination of the biosphere. The six 10 minute episodes are: 1. “The Concept of energy flow”, 2. “Photosynthesis”, 3. “Energy flow in the ecosystem”, 4. “Energy flow at cellular level”, 5. “Energy flow in agriculture”, 6. “Energy flow in the biosphere.”

results.title: Cellular respiration
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and TV Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: biology”.
These six 10 minute programs use computer animation to illustrate facets of biological respiration. They begin with a historical perspective, and gradually proceed into modern research and theories, examining enzymes, coensymes, phosphorylation, biosynthesis, glycolysis and the citric acid cycle. The programs include: 1. Metabolism 4. Fermentation 2. Glycolysis 5. Krebs cycle 3. Redox reactions in glycolysis 6. Energy flow in respiration
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and TV Ontario

results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontario
results.brief_description: This series is designed to be used as a teaching tool to explain concepts in physics. Each tape consists six episodes and each concept is accompanied by excellent computer graphics and explanatory diagrams.

results.title: The Kinetic theory of matter. Parts 1-4
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: physics”.
Presents episodes 1-4 - Diffusion, Expansion, Pressure and Compressibility. Relates properties of solids, liquids and gases - such as diffusion, expansion, pressure and compressibility - to the kinetic theory of matter. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.description:

results.title: Electromagnetism
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: physics”.
The historical discovery of the magnetic properties of lodestone led to a scientific understanding of Earth’s magnetic field. Six ten minute computer-animated episodes explore this mysterious force from early experiments to the concepts of electromagnetic induction, the motor principle, generators, and transformers. It also looks at fascinating modern theories about the role of the Earth’s magnetic field in the extinction of species and at the ways that animals use it for navigation. The programs include: 1. Earth’s magnetic field 4. The Motor principle 2. Magnetism and electron flow 5. Electromagnetic induction 3. Domain theory 6. Life in the field

results.title: Electricity
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: physics”.
Addresses the fundamentals of electrostatics and current electricity, helping students to form images of abstract concepts. The first three programs on electrostatics explains the charging of objects by contact and induction. The last three episodes on current electricity looks at electrical charge, current flow, potentail difference and resistance.

results.title: Nuclear physics
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: physics”.
Shows step-by-step, how an interest in cathode rays led scientists to discover X-rays, then alpha, beta and gamma radiation, and finally explore the conversion of matter into energy. Vivid computer animation clarifies concepts such as nuclear fission and fusion, shows how a nuclear reactor works and the difficulties in the disposal of radioactive wastes. There six ten minute episodes are: 1. “The Discovery of radioactivity” 2. “Properties of Becquerel rays” 3. “Natural transmutations” 4. “Energy from the nucleus” 5. “Electrical energy from fission” 6. “Nuclear by-products.”
